title-group.article-title: An entropy generation and genetic algorithm optimization of two-bed adsorption cooling cycle

abstract.p: This article presents the performance analysis of adsorption cooling, shortly AD, system using a thermodynamic framework with an entropy generation analysis. The model captures the transient and the cyclic steady-state performances of the adsorption–desorption cycles operating under assorted heat source temperatures. Type-RD silica gel, with a pore surface area of 720 m2/g and diameters 0.4–0.7 mm, is used as an adsorbent and its high affinity for thewater vapour adsorbate gives a high equilibrium uptake. The key advantages of the AD are (a) it has no moving parts rendering less maintenance and (b) the energy efficient means of cooling by the adsorption process with a low-temperature heat source and (c) it is environmental friendly with low carbon footprint. By incorporating the genetic algorithm onto the entropy minimization technique, it is possible to locate the optimal system performance point or the global minima with respect to entropy generation using the system parameters such as coolant and heat source water temperatures, heat transfer areas, etc. The system analysis shows that the minimization of entropy generation in the AD cycle leads to the maximization of the coefficient of performance and this translates into a higher delivery of useful cooling effects at the particular input resource temperature.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p:
The adsorption chillers have been gaining more attention in the recent decades due to its following merits: (a) capturing low-temperature waste heat for the conversion into useful effects, (b) low fouling, (c) cycle has almost no moving parts, and (d) the cycle is environment friendly. Figure 1 shows the schematic of a basic two-bed adsorption chiller which represents the most basic configuration in such an adsorption system. Adsorption chiller employs adsorption-desorption processes of the adsorbate by the adsorbent and cooling is produced at the evaporator. Details pertaining to the operation of such a two-bed adsorption chiller could be easily found in the earlier literature [1, 2]. In this context, silica gel–water has been selected as the adsorbent–adsorbate pair due to its relatively low regeneration temperature (typically about 65°C to 85°C). This working pair enjoys a large uptake capacity for water which in turn has a high latent heat of evaporation, typically up to 40 per cent of the silica gel dry mass [3]. Although an adsorption cooling, shortly AD, system is environmentally friendly, it is recognized to be inefficient due to lower system coefficient of performance (COP) as compared to mechanical chiller, yet the AD system utilizes the low-grade waste heat which is considered free. Fig. 1
Schematic layout diagram of an AD system

Hence, the motivation for this article is to investigate irreversibility production or entropy generation which contributes to the inefficiency of AD cycle. In addition, we employ an entropy generation minimization procedure which is formulated to minimize the dissipative or lost work of the batch-operated cycles. Such a technique effectively identifies the conditions needed for an optimal operation, leading to the overall maximization of the COP of the apparatus. It differs from the conventional entropy-related approaches found in literature because it tracks the minimum specific entropy generation that occurs at a supplied heat-source temperature.

A transient modelling is developed to simulate the batch-operated cycle of the AD. In addition to the heat and mass transfers in each of the major components of an adsorption cycle, the model incorporated the entropy generation of the adsorbent–adsorbate beds when exposed to vapour uptake or desorption, the evaporator, and the condenser. The thermodynamic framework of the Gibbs free energy is employed and a detailed discussion on the entropy generation equations under the cyclic steady state will be presented in sections to follow. The entropy generation minimization technique is enhanced with a genetic algorithm (GA) [4, 5] procedure which is used to identify global minima for specific entropy generation.

sec.title: 2 SYSTEM DESCRIPTION
sec.p: The adsorption cooling cycle is one of the environmental friendly methods to produce cooling by utilizing the low-grade waste heat source, typically 65–85°C. The AD cycle comprises three major components: (1) the evaporator, (2) the condenser, and (3) regenerative adsorber and desorber beds where the adsorbent is placed. Figure 1 shows the schematic layout of AD cycle. As shown in Fig. 1, the condensate from the condenser is depressurized through the U-tube and sent to the evaporator where the external cooling load is employed as the heating medium to maintain the evaporation, from chilled water flowing inside the tubing, is supplied. The evaporation is achieved by the water vapour uptake by the adsorbent (type-RD silica gel). The evaporation process is enhanced by a spray system using the full-cone-type nozzles. The water vapour emanating from the evaporator is absorbed by the unsaturated silica gel which is packed into a tube-fin heat exchanger housed inside the reactor beds. A continuous vapour uptake is achieved when the vapour valve is opened. Owing to its exothermic nature of the adsorption process, the heat is released during the vapour uptake and the adsorption process would continue to a preset cycle time. In general, the cycle time in the adsorption process is one of the input parameters used to control the cycle performance. The saturated silica gel (performed adsorption process in the previous half cycle) could be now regenerated by introducing a low-grade waste heat source, typically 65°C to 85°C, and this is known as desorption process. The waste heat source or solar energy is supplied to the saturated reactor beds to regenerate the water vapour. With the vapour valve set to open position, the regenerated water vapour flows to the cooler surfaces of a water-cooled tubing inside the condenser and it condenses through the U-tube and is sent to the evaporator where the cooling effect is produced. The condensation process is accompanied by the rejection of latent heat of condensation into the cooling water passing inside the tubing in the condenser.

The AD cycle operates in batch-type process to achieve the useful effect using two reactor beds, cycling one of reactor beds as adsorption mode while the other is in desorption mode during the first half cycle of operation. The roles of the reactor beds are reversed in next half cycle. Prior to switching their roles, pre-cooling of desorber bed and pre-heating of adsorber beds need to be performed for a short period, which is known as a switching process.

The temperature is uniform across the adsorbent layer.
The adsorption of water vapour by silica gel inside the adsorber beds is uniform.
Both the adsorbent and the adsorbate gas phases are in equilibrium.

sec.title: 3.2 Modelling of entropy generation for AD cycle
sec.p: Entropy and the entropy generation formulation will be presented in this section. The concept of entropy is defined by the second law of thermodynamics which states that the entropy of a closed system always increases or remains constant. Thus, entropy is also a measure of the tendency of a process, such as a chemical reaction, to be entropically favoured, or to proceed in a particular direction. It determines that thermal energy always flows spontaneously from regions of higher temperature to regions of lower temperature, in the form of heat. These processes reduce the state of order of the initial systems, and therefore, entropy is an expression of disorder or randomness. This model is the basis of the microscopic interpretation of entropy in statistical mechanics describing the probability of the constituents of a thermodynamic system to be occupying accessible quantum mechanical states; a model directly related to the information entropy. The general entropy balance for a system can be expressed as follows (22) where the first term represents the entropy change in the system and the second term that in the surrounding. The entropy change in the surrounding can be represented as (23)

The term on the left-hand side of equation (23) represents the Gibbs free energy. The same approach isapplied for the entropy generation analysis for AD cycle.

The fins of the heat exchanging tube are considered to be relatively small, typically 25.4 mm in height. Thus, it can be well approximated that the temperature of adsorbent, adsorbate, and the heat exchanging material are considered to be an average temperature. The overall entropy generation of bed, ignoring heat losses, interacting with the evaporator can be represented as the sum of entropy generations contributed by heat transfer, mass transfer, and flushing of coolant in the bed. The first term on the right-hand side of equation (27) represents the contribution of entropy generation by mass transfer; the second term that contributed by heat transfer with the coolant; the third term that due to superheating of incoming refrigerant; and finally, the last term, or the external entropy generation, the irreversibility due to flushing of coolant out of the heat exchanger tube. The coefficient δ is unity for adsorption and zero for desorption. The global entropy generation of the bed which is interacting with thecondenser, ignoring heat loss to the ambient, is the sum of the internal entropy generation contributed by mass transfer, heat transfer between the bed and the water in the heat exchanger tube, and external entropy generation due to flushing by the heat source. However, since the condenser of the heat exchanging tubes have been chosen to be corrugated by the manufacturer, a thin film of condensate is retained on the surface. Therefore, the condenser pressure is always maintained at the refrigerant’s saturated vapour pressure. As a result, if dqbed,jdt>0, when the value of θ switches is zero and it results in dqbed,jdt=0, i.e. no condensate will be induced to be evaporated.

sec.title: 4 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p:
The governing equations are solved by the fifth-order Gear’s backward differential method of the DIVPAG subroutine of IMSL Fortran library subroutines. The iterative scheme uses a double-precision format which has a tolerance of 1 × 10−6. Numerical calculations were performed for a nominal capacity of 3 Rton (10.5 kW; Rton, refrigeration tonnes) AD system. The consistency of the simulation model was checked with suitable range of parameters that is anticipated of the chiller operation domain. The hot water source temperatures are varied from 65°C to 85°C while the cooling water and the chilled water temperatures are kept at around 29°C ± 1° and 12°C ± 1°, and the cooling output is monitored for the entropy generation. The cycle time is fixed at 660 s while switching time is set at 25 s. Figure 2 depicts the predicted and experimental temperature time history of the adsorber, the desorber, the condenser, and the evaporator when the supplied heat source temperature is 80°C, and the system is assumed to start from cold state. It is observed the predicted results agree well with the experimentally measured results. Fig. 2
The temperature time history of simulated result and experimental results

Figure 3 shows the simulated and experimental temperature profiles of outlet hot water and cooling water from the beds, the condenser cooling water, and the chilled water from the condenser and the evaporator, respectively. It is observed that cycle average temperature difference between inlet and outlet of cooling water and chilled water temperature is 5°C and 2.5°C, respectively, while cycle average temperature difference between inlet and outlet of cooling water and hot water temperature is 5°C and 8°C. The simulated uptake profiles of the desorber and the adsorber is illustrated in Fig. 4. It is found out that cycle average uptake is achieved as 10 per cent of the amount of adsorbent packed in the system. The entropy generation of the main components in an AD cycle is also simulated using the Gibbs free energy approach. Fig. 3

Figure 5 illustrates the predicted entropy generation profiles of major components in the AD cycle. As it is mentioned in Section 2, the system comprises couples of regenerative reactors, an evaporator, and the condenser. The adsorbent is packed on the fins-tube heat exchanger coils stacked on the support inthe reactor bed. It is observed that the entropy generation during the switching period is the highest for the adsorber and the desorber since the pre-heating and pre-cooling of the adsorber bed and the desorber bed in which the temperature gradient of the bed and the incoming fluid media is significantly huge, resulting in the high entropy generation. Thus, entropy generation due to heat transfer between the beds and the cooling or heating medium contributes to such a high entropy generation profiles. The experimental entropy generation analysis has been analysed for 3 Rton AD cycle at a heat source temperature of 80°C while cooling water and chilled water inlet temperature are fixed at 29°C and 12°C, respectively. The entropy generation contributes to the inefficiency of the system and could be optimized as a system with optimal operation condition which renders optimal performance. Thus, the entropy generation analysis is performed at assorted heat source temperature. The predicted entropy generation data at assorted heat source temperature for AD cycle is outlined in Table 3 along with experimentally computed entropy generation at a heat source temperature of 80°C. The results in Table 3 shows that the system entropy generation, cooling capacity, and heat supplied to the system are increasing with increase in heat source temperature while COP decreases beyond a heat source temperature of 80°C. This decline in COP is due to the increase in irreversibility of the AD cycle at a higher heat source temperature. Thus, the optimal performance of AD cycle at a heat source temperature could be found by introducing the parameter, namely, specific entropy generation, which is defined as the ratio of total entropy generation and the cooling capacity at a corresponding heat source temperature. The entropy generation is contributed by two processes: (a) entropy generation due to heat transfer and (b) entropy generation by mass transfer. The predicted entropy generation by aforementioned processes is presented in Table 4. It is noticed that only 12 per cent and 9 per cent is contributed by mass transfer effect in the adsorber and the desorber, respectively. However, 35 per cent and 20 per cent of entropy generation in the evaporator and the condenser is due to mass transfer effect. Figure 8 shows the predicted entropy generation and cooling capacity of AD cycle as well as the experimental results at the assorted heat source temperature. It is observed that the experiment data agrees well with the predicted results within the 5–7 per cent range. The experimental specific entropy generation AD cycle is 35.5 K−1 while the predicted value about 41.76 K−1. The results show that optimal performance is found while the specific entropy generation is minimal. Thus, the specific entropy generation is a key parameter to analyse the effect of heat source on the performance of the AD cycle to optimize the performance of each of the main components in an AD cycle. Since the adsorption and desorption take place in a batch manner, another key parameter to be taken into consideration is the cycle time of the AD system. The effect of cycle time on the cooling capacity, COP of the system, and specific entropy generation is depicted in Fig. 10(a) and (b). The shorter cycle time leads to the lower COP since more thermal energy is needed and more entropy generation, although the system generates more cooling capacity. However, it should be noticed that the quality of cooling is deteriorating for the longer cycle time, although the thermal energy supplied and entropy generation are significantly reduced. This causes the COP of the system to decrease beyond 1360 s. Using the specific entropy generation, the optimal cycle time of the system is found to be at 1360 s where the COP of the system is maximum and specific entropy generation minimum. Minimization of specific entropy generation is performed using GA which could give the global minima solution for an AD cycle. The block diagram for the GA procedure is illustrated in Fig. 11(a). As shown in this figure, GA comprises four main stages: (a) initialization of variables, (b) selection (c) reproduction, and (d) termination of program. GA initializes the variables in prescribed ranges of variables and does the fitness test of the objective function which is to be optimized. The sensitivity of GA on the objective function is shown in Fig. 11(b). The sensitive part of GA is reproduction which includes two different parts: (a) crossover and (b) mutation of the variables. When a GA procedure, which looks for the gradient in the search space, is applied, with respect to multi-parameters such as (a) the hot water flowrates, (b) the heat transfer area of adsorber and desorber beds (c) the hot water and cooling water inlet temperatures, and (d) cooling water flowrates, the global minima of specific entropy generation at 38.8 K−1 is obtained – a reduction of 9 per cent from the conventional procedure while the experimental entropy generation is about 36.2 K−1. This minimum occurs at a neighbourhood heat source temperature of 80.9°C while the cooling capacity is increased by 8 per cent. The ranges and optimal solution generated from GA optimization method are presented in Table 5. Figure 12 comparesthe two minimization procedures and it also depicts the maximum COP of the AD system, which occurs exactly when the specific entropy generation is the lowest. It is observed that COP is improved by 6percent under GA optimization methods while specific entropy generation is reduced by 9 per cent and the results is closer to the experimental value of within the 5–8 per cent range. sec.title: 5 CONCLUSION
sec.p: A second law analysis with specific entropy minimization has been successfully demonstrated using the thermodynamic framework approach and later optimized with a GA tool. It captures first the contributions of entropy generation of the key components of an AD cycle at the global optima. The cyclic steady-state contributions to the overall entropy generation of the cycle are 30 per cent by the adsorber beds, 34 per cent by the desorber beds, 23 per cent by the condenser, and 9 per cent by the evaporator. Due to an increase in internal dissipation of beds and a drop in the cooling capacity of AD at the higher heat source temperatures, a broad minima is observed at a temperature of 80°C that is supplied to the cycle. Furthermore, when the GA is applied, the specific entropy generation yielded a lower value of 38.8 K−1 at the minima. The experimental measurements of specific entropy generation and COP for an AD system validated these simulated results and were found to be in good agreement with the data points with an accuracy of 5 per cent. The drop in entropy generation of an AD cycle demonstrates the effectiveness of entropy generation as a methodology for performance evaluation, leading to the maximization of COP. The concept analyses the internal changes of the thermodynamic cycles, and it could be extended to a host of heat-activated devices operating under atemperature cascade.
